trigger.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to make something happen very quickly, especially a series of events
trigger.translation[0].definitions[0].no: trigger a memory (=make you suddenly remember something)
trigger.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The assassination triggered off a wave of rioting.
Certain forms of mental illness can be triggered by food allergies.
His action triggered a massive response from the government.
trigger.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to make something such as a bomb or electrical system start to operate
trigger.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The burglars fled after triggering the alarm.
trigger.translation[1].definitions[0].de: the part of a gun that you pull with your finger to fire it
trigger.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: He took aim and squeezed the trigger.
trigger.translation[2].definitions[0].de: to make something start happening, especially a series of events
trigger.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: The move could trigger a rush by investors to buy annuities.
a sales rush triggered by cuts in interest rates
trigger.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to be the thing that quickly causes something to happen, especially a problem
trigger.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: A quick-fix solution could be a trigger for higher inflation.
